results.title: ‘Starting a Fire’: U.S. and China Enter Dangerous Territory over Taiwan
results.abstract: The self-ruled island has moved to the heart of deepening discord and rivalry between the two superpowers, with the potential to ignite military conflagration and reshape the regional order.
results.byline: By Chris Buckley and Steven Lee Myers

multimedia.caption: Taiwanese helicopters flying through Taipei, the capital. China’s growing military might has for the first time made a conquest of Taiwan conceivable, perhaps even tempting.

results.title: At Rwanda’s Favorite Bars, Forget the Beer: Milk Is What’s on Tap
results.abstract: Milk is a favorite drink in Rwanda, and milk bars serve it up in abundance, fresh or fermented, hot or cold. “When you drink milk, you always have your head straight and your ideas right.”

results.abstract: Amid the uncertainty that lies ahead under a Taliban-controlled government, Afghans reflect on the final months of fighting.

results.abstract: After insisting he would remain in office amid a criminal investigation, Sebastian Kurz announced he would step aside to resolve a government crisis.

results.title: Philippines’ Nobel Prize Newsroom Is Overjoyed but Under Siege
results.abstract: Rappler, the news site co-founded by the new Nobel laureate Maria Ressa, dares to criticize the Philippine president, Rodrigo Duterte. He may yet see it shut down.

multimedia.caption: Rappler staff in their office in Manila in 2018. The news site’s future is precarious, even after one of its founders was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize on Friday.

results.abstract: There’s a cognitive dissonance between Mr. Johnson’s upbeat appraisal of British life and the ills facing its citizens, including gas and food shortages and fears of rising energy prices.

results.title: Sexual Abuse Revelations Accelerate Sense of a French Church in Retreat
results.abstract: The abuse of more than 200,000 minors by clergy over the past seven decades has shaken the nation and what was once a pillar of French society.
results.byline: By Norimitsu Onishi and Aurelien Breeden

multimedia.caption: Easter celebrations in Paris last year. The Catholic Church in France has been weakened further than its counterparts across the world, especially in Germany and the United States.

results.title: Global Deal to End Tax Havens Moves Ahead as Nations Back 15% Rate
results.abstract: More than 130 countries agreed to set a minimum tax rate of 15 percent as governments look to end a race to the bottom on corporate taxation.

org_facet: Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development

results.title: Chinese Journalist Detained After Criticizing Government-Sponsored Blockbuster
results.abstract: The police arrested Luo Changping on Thursday, two days after he questioned China’s role in the Korean War, the subject of China’s box office hit “The Battle at Lake Changjin.”
results.byline: By Steven Lee Myers and Amy Chang Chien

results.abstract: As diplomats from both countries began negotiating a new security agreement on Friday, the focus was on stopping criminal activity while the border crisis was conspicuously sidestepped.
results.byline: By Lara Jakes and Maria Abi-Habib

results.title: Chicago’s mayor guts the city’s vaccine mandate for public workers.
results.abstract: A day after President Biden visited to issue a national plea for more vaccine mandates, Mayor Lori Lightfoot said Chicago’s public workers could opt out of the city’s until the end of the year by getting regularly tested.

multimedia.caption: A view of Chicago last winter. Mayor Lori Lightfoot said on Friday that city employees could avoid the vaccine mandate she issued in August by getting tested twice a week through the end of the year.

results.title: See How Britain’s Gas Shortages Became a Crisis Overnight
results.abstract: New data reveals how panic buying drained supplies, exacerbating a problem stemming from a lack of trained drivers to make fuel deliveries.

results.title: Court in Argentina Dismisses Charges Against Kirchner in Bombing Case
results.abstract: Cristina Fernández de Kirchner, now the vice president, had been accused of conspiring with Iran to thwart an investigation into a 1994 attack on a Jewish center in Buenos Aires.

multimedia.caption: Vice President Cristina Fernández de Kirchner last month in Buenos Aires. The ruling late Thursday is the latest legal victory for Mrs. Kirchner, who was president of Argentina from 2007 to 2015.

results.title: Nobel laureate from Russia says he would have chosen a different Russian.
results.abstract: Supporters of the jailed Russian opposition leader Aleksei Navalny say he should have won the Nobel Peace Prize. The Russian journalist who won, Dmitri A. Muratov, agrees.
